title: AB 933
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature declares that the Fixing America’s Surface Transportation (FAST) Act, passed by Congress in 2015, provides long-term funding for surface transportation and mandates the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) to award certain grants through rulemaking. The FAST Act, passed in 2015, provides long-term funding for surface transportation and mandates NHTSA to award grants through rulemaking. It includes grant programs for states meeting requirements for impaired driving interventions, such as 24/7 Sobriety programs. These programs focus on high-risk offenders and are pursuant to Sections 402 and 405 of Title 23 of the United States Code. The FAST Act mandates NHTSA to award grants for impaired driving interventions like 24/7 Sobriety programs. California aims to implement a statewide program to qualify for FAST Act funding. Section 23582.5 of the Vehicle Code allows courts to order individuals convicted of DUI offenses to participate in a qualified 24/7 Sobriety program as a condition of probation, parole, or sentence if certain criteria are met. The court may require a person arrested for DUI to enroll in a qualified 24/7 Sobriety program as a condition of release on bond if certain criteria are met. A person with a suspended or revoked driving privilege can enroll in a 24/7 Sobriety program to obtain a restricted driving privilege if they committed a violation within 10 years of a previous DUI conviction. The program may be required as a condition for the restricted driving privilege. If a person commits a violation within 10 years of a previous DUI conviction, they can enroll in a 24/7 Sobriety program to obtain a restricted driving privilege. This privilege may be conditioned on participation in the program as an alternative to or in conjunction with an ignition interlock device program. A person subject to this subdivision must participate in the 24/7 Sobriety program for a minimum of one year. A "24/7 Sobriety program" requires participants to abstain from alcohol or controlled substances, undergo frequent testing, and face immediate sanctions for violations. The program must be evidence-based, meeting specific criteria. Evaluation research confirms that the 24/7 Sobriety program produces positive results attributed to the program itself, peer-reviewed by experts, and endorsed by federal agencies or respected research organizations. Participants may also be required to participate in other DUI programs as mandated by California law. The 24/7 Sobriety program must be endorsed by a federal agency or respected research organization. Participants may also be required to join other DUI programs as per California law. Testing locations and methods should prioritize sanctioning violations promptly after they occur. The court shall impose a program of no more than 180 days unless the defendant tests positive for alcohol or drugs or fails to appear for a test, with costs based on ability to pay. The court may impose a program up to 180 days if the defendant tests positive for alcohol or drugs or misses a test. The Office of Traffic Safety must include provisions for the 24/7 Sobriety program in its highway safety plan. The department will establish uniform data collection and reporting statewide. The department will establish statewide uniform collection and reporting of participant demographic information, case history, testing details, and fees. Section 1808 of the Vehicle Code is being amended. Section 1808 of the Vehicle Code is amended to allow public inspection of department records related to vehicle registration, driver's license applications, convictions, and accident reports, except in cases where confidentiality is required by law. Law enforcement agencies and courts can access accident reports. The department in Sacramento provides abstracts of convictions and accident reports for public access. The time limits for availability are ten years for certain violations, seven years for two-point violations, and three years for accidents and other violations. The Department in Sacramento provides abstracts of convictions and accident reports for public access. Violations designated as two points have a seven-year time limit for availability, while accidents and other violations have a three-year limit. Driver's license suspension actions are disclosed only during the actual suspension period. The Department in Sacramento provides abstracts of convictions and accident reports for public access, with specific time limits for availability. Driver's license suspension actions are disclosed only during the actual suspension period, and certain personal information is protected under the Driver’s Privacy Protection Act of 1994. The Department in Sacramento provides abstracts of convictions for a period of 10 years from the date of the offense for the purpose of imposing penalties mandated by this code or other applicable state law. The Department in Sacramento provides abstracts of convictions for a period of 10 years from the date of the offense to courts and law enforcement agencies for imposing penalties mandated by Section 23550.5 or other applicable state law for certain felony convictions. Consent to use a driver's license number for obtaining motor vehicle records is presumed if the number is provided for insurance coverage or employment eligibility purposes. The insurance agent or broker is authorized to transmit motor vehicle records for specific purposes. They are not responsible for the handling of the record by authorized recipients. Prior to transmitting records, insurance brokers or agents must obtain a written agreement from insurers or third parties to handle the records in compliance with state and federal laws on fair credit reporting and privacy.
